Events, Center for Latin American and Caribbean Studies (CLACS) | NYU                           NEW YORK UNIVERSITY       ARTS AND SCIENCE       COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE       GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE                                                                                                             About Us       People       Undergraduate       Graduate Program       Faculty Resources       Alumni Network       Caribbean Initiative       Andean Initiative       Quechua Language       K-12 Outreach       Events           See Also           > Each semester, CLACS hosts a Research Colloquium series which combines a graduate level course with a speaker series. The title for the Spring 2015 Colloquium series is "Latin American Independence in the Age of Revolution." ">Research Colloquium Series       > Working Group Events       > Perspectives from the Field Series       > Brown Bag Seminars       > Film Series Events       > WiPLASH Events       > K-12 Outreach Events       > Past Events       > CLACS Events Calendar                   Home > Events     Events       Calendar            Join Our Mailing List   Events RSS Feed                                , -               Special Series/Events   Indigenous Peoples   Transnational Voices: Bridging Goals and Challenges of Producing Indigenous Radio, from New York to Latin America   Presenter: Kichwa Hatari   CLACS sponsored event on indigenous radio, organized by Kichwa Hatari               Location:             United Nations FF Building 304 E 45th St. Room FF 1507A, New York, NY, 10017        Read More...                  , -               Special Series/Events   Lecture Series   The Cuban Moment   Presenter: Ted Piccone, Ted Henken   The second edition of The Cuban Moment, features a conversation on the latest developments related to the economy of Cuba and U.S. foreign policy towards the caribbean island. Ted Piccone of the Brookings Institute and Ted Henken, professor at Baruch College, will be our guest speakers for this event. The Cuban Moment is a co-sponsorship with the King Juan Carlos I of Spain Center, and is organized by Ana Dopico and Jill Lane.               Location:             KJCC Auditorium, 53 Washington Square South, New York, NY, 10012 (map)         Read More...                  , -               Special Series/Events   Lecture   Quilombo do Presente: The Contemporary Political and Territorial Issues Facing Brazil's Maroon Communities   Presenter: Mariléa de Andrade, José Maurício Arruti   Scholarly presentations by Professors Mariléa de Andrade and José Maurício Arruti of the Universidade Estadual de Campinas.               Location:             Columbia University, 420 West 118th St. between Amsterdam and Morningside Drive (map)     Read More...                  , -               Special Series/Events   Brazilian Initiative   Where Slaves Were Slaveowners: The Case of 19th-Century Bahia, Brazil   Presenter: João Reis   As part of the Brazilian Initiative at CLACS, João Reis presents a lecture about slavery's history in Brazil.               Location:             KJCC Auditorium 53 Washington Square South, New York, NY, 10012 (map)         Read More...                  , -               Special Series/Events   Performance and lecture   Quilombo do Futuro: The Contemporary Social and Cultural Resonance of Brazil's Maroon Communities   Presenter: Maga Bo (DJ/Producer), BNegão (Vocalist), Mariléa de Andrade   Join us for a musical performance and lecture that will situate the artists' work in a social context by addressing some of the contemporary challenges and successes of the quilombo movement in present-day Brazil.               Location:             KJCC Auditorium, 53 Washington Square South, New York, NY, 10012 (map)      Read More...                  , -               Special Series/Events   Student Research   Library and Archives Research Workshop   Presenter: Edgardo Pérez Morales, Dylon Robbins,   As part of our continuing efforts on professional development, CLACS will offer a workshop on Library and Archives Research.               Location:             53 Washington Square South, KJCC room 404, New York, NY, 10012 map     Read More...                   - , -               Special Series/Events   Conference   José Antonio Aponte and His World: Writing, Painting, and Making Freedom in the African Diaspora   “José Antonio Aponte and His World: Writing, Painting, and Making Freedom in the African Diaspora” brings together scholars to discuss the current state of “Apontian” studies and suggest future directions for scholarship.                    Location:             King Juan Carlos I of Spain Center (KJCC) Auditorium, 53 Washington Square South, New York University, New York NY 10012 (map)     Read More...                   - , -               Special Series/Events   Conference   Conferência 2015 PLH: Teoria e práctica lado a lado   O objetivo desta conferência é oportunizar um espaço de discussão no qual possamos somar experiências e vivências. As apresentações serão feitas em forma de diálogo de modo a destacar o que pode ser feito e o que realmente acontece, as metodologias, mas também desafios, sempre de forma contextualizada, com números, mas também com faces.               Location:             King Juan Carlos I of Spain Center (KJCC), 53 Washington Square South, New York University, New York NY 10012 (map)     Read More...                                                         Contact Us | © New York University , Arts and Science

Politics of the Caribbean Nations        V53.0532   Politics of the Caribbean Nations   Professor Christopher Mitchell   Fall, 2002   COURSE OUTLINE AND READING LIST   Course requirements : (1) Reading : required readings are assigned   for all topics. Please keep up with the reading carefully; it will be discussed   in class and doing well on exams will depend on mastering the reading. Please   treat handouts distributed in class as assigned readings. Almost all books   may be bought in the NYU Bookstore, and all will be available in the Reserve   Room, on Level A in Bobst Library; Raymond Carrs Puerto Rico: A Colonial   Experiment will only be on reserve. (2) Attendance in class :   its important to participate regularly in class discussions, and attendance   will be taken. (3) Mid-term exam : there will be a one-hour exam in class,   on October 17 . It will include both a short-answer section and an essay   section; both will be designed to test full understanding of the reading. This   mid-term will count for 25% of a student's final grade. (4) Book review:   There will be one seven-page book review, on a book to be chosen from the list   just below in this syllabus; the review will be due in class on November   19 . Details on the book review format will be distributed in class; the   review will count for 25% of a student's final grade. (5) Final exam :   a two-hour final, including both essays and short-answer questions, will be   held on December 17 from 10 to 11:50 AM . Please do not schedule any   travel that would conflict with this exam date. The final will cover the full   course, and will count for 50% of a student's final grade.        Office hours : Professor Mitchell holds office hours on   Mondays, from 2:00 to 4:30 PM, at 715 Broadway, Room 420. Please sign up on   the sheet posted on the office door, or e-mail <cm3@nyu.edu> for a specific   appointment. If you have class on Mondays at that hour, an alternate will be   arranged.            Books that may be read for the assigned book review :   (all have been placed on reserve in Bobst Library, A level):   Jorge Heine, The Last Cacique: Leadership and Politics in a Puerto Rican   City (Pittsburgh: University of Pittsburgh Press, 1993)   Ana Julia Jatar-Hausmann, The Cuban Way: Capitalism, Communism and Confrontation   (West Hartford, CT: Kumarian Press, 1999) together with   Susan Kaufman Purcell and David Rothkopf, eds., Cuba: The Contours of Change   (Boulder, CO: Lynne Rienner Publishers, 2000)   Peggy Levitt, The Transnational Villagers (on the process and effect   of Dominican migration to the United States) (Berkeley and Los Angeles: University   of California Press, 2001)   Gordon K. Lewis, Grenada: The Jewel Despoiled (Baltimore: The Johns   Hopkins University Press, 1987)   Michel-Rolph Trouillot, Haiti: State Against Nation: The Origins and Legacy   of Duvalierism (New York: Monthly Review Press, 1990)   TOPICS AND READINGS   I Introduction and Overview of the Course -- September 5   II Caribbean history and geography -- September 10, 12, 17, 19   Reading : Franklin W. Knight, The Caribbean: The Genesis of a Fragmented   Nationalism (New York: Oxford University Press, 2nd edition 1990),    pp. 1-331.   III The politics of Hispanic societies in the Caribbean   A. The Dominican Republic -- Sept. 24, 26, Oct. 1 and 3   Reading : Jonathan Hartlyn, The Struggle for Democratic Politics in   the Dominican Republic (Chapel Hill, NC: University of North Carolina Press,   1998), pp. 3-59, 134-279.   B. Cuba -- October 8, 10, 15   Reading : Marifeli Prez-Stable, The Cuban Revolution: Origins, Course,   and Legacy (NY: Oxford University Press, 1993), pp. 36-181.   The mid-term exam will be held in   class on Thursday, October 17. It will cover all material in the course through   Prez-Stables book The Cuban Revolution   C. Puerto Rico October 22, 24, 29   Reading : Raymond Carr, Puerto Rico: A Colonial Experiment (New   York: Vintage, 1984), pp. 1-244. (Available on reserve in Bobst Library)   IV Politics of Anglo-Caribbean nations: Jamaica, Guyana, Grenada October   31, November 5, 7, 12   Reading : Anthony Payne and Paul Sutton, eds., Modern Caribbean Politics   (Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press, 1993), Chapters 1, 4, 6 and   7.   Book reviews are due at the start   of class on November 19   V Politics in Haiti Nov. 14, 19, 21   Reading : Robert Fatton, Jr., Haitis Predatory Republic: The Unending   Transition to Democracy (Boulder, CO: Lynne Rienner Publishers, 2002), Chapters   2 through 6.
